div.p: Audit Mechanisms for Privacy Protection in Healthcare
Joint work with Jeremiah Blocki, Nicolas Christin and Arunesh Sinha
Position } Audit mechanisms are essential for privacy protection in
healthcare environments } Guided by comprehensive study of HIPAA Privacy Rule

} Principled audit mechanisms based on machine learning and economics can be used to provide operational guidance to organizations on how to conduct audits } For grey policy concepts: was access for purpose of
treatment or curiosity, financial gain etc.?
Auditing budget: $3000/ cycle Cost for one inspection: $100 Only 30 inspections per cycle
Consider 4 possible allocations of the available 30 inspections
Choose allocation probabilistically based on weights
Learning from experience: weights updated using observed and estimated loss
Regret Minimizing Audits } Learns from experience to recommend budget allocation
for audit in each audit cycle } Observed loss used to estimate loss for each action and
update probabilities for actions } Budget allocation is provably close to optimal fixed strategy
} Technical approach: New regret minimization algorithm for repeated games of imperfect information
(Online learning-theoretic technique) J. Blocki, N. Christin, A. Datta, A. Sinha, Regret Minimizing Audits: A Learning
Theoretic Basis for Privacy Protection, CSF, June 2011.
} Identifying experts } Can experts be learned from logs?
} Experimental evaluation } Real hospital logs, user studies
